paragraphs.name: 1bea
paragraphs.text: So next time you want to learn a new language, go ahead and take the plunge! Find an open source project to contribute to and march ahead on the path to learning that language and it’s nuances ;)
Once again, I started looking for open source projects in Go which had some “beginner” or “easy-fix” issues. I found a project by Google which is basically a Go wrapper for GitHub’s REST API.
paragraphs.name: 5e3a
2b16
paragraphs.text: This is like getting a free-of-cost personal guidance about how to write good code.
My contribution graph for last 1 year (https://github.com/sahildua2305)
paragraphs.name: bcbe
bfb3
paragraphs.text: I had my first PR on that project 2 days after I started learning Go.

paragraphs.name: 8bf2
paragraphs.text: I have developed more than 20 mini projects while learning different languages. Trust me, when you write code for your personal project which may be a weekend project or an overnight quick hack, you write code to get something done. All you care about is — “Does my code work?”. You hardly care about the quality of the code.

paragraphs.name: 47d1
paragraphs.text: I started reading about syntax of Perl and started understanding some of the common patterns of the language. Now, I really wanted to build something using Perl so that I could apply my knowledge of the language and practice various concepts of the language. While I was looking for ideas to build something in Perl, I came across DuckDuckGo’s open source organization on GitHub. I noticed that some of the open projects were written in Perl. I had a look at the issues and found a lot of “beginner” issues. I immediately started working on them and submitted a couple of pull requests. Fast forward to today, I am one of the main contributors for a couple of their open projects and also one of the 20 Open Source Community Leaders for DuckDuckGo.

paragraphs.name: 6bf3
paragraphs.text: Not just that, you have a chance to look at the rest of the code and see how well it’s written and/or documented.

Right after I learnt the syntax of Perl, I started contributing to open source projects. While doing so, I always used to look at the existing modules. I used to notice the patterns being used in Perl. Hence, I started picking up those good practices in my own code and it helped me in learning how to write good code in Perl.
